title: META Request: Subject: FOI/EIR Request Regarding Claim of Turret Collapse at the Market Tavern on 10 January

content:
Dear Sheffield City Council,
I would like copies of any information you hold concerning your handling of my recent Freedom of Information request. The requestor would like to understand the processing of this request, why it was not responded to on time nor why it was not fulfilled by an extended deadline.
As such, please action the following FOI request:
Please provide me with copies of all internal correspondence about the processing of my Freedom of Information request of Freedom of Information Request” FOI/EIR Request Regarding Claim of Turret Collapse at the Market Tavern on 10 January” .
Records will in include but not be limited to, those of the FOI team reaching out to record custodians, record custodians discussing their statutory response, any advice sought, and the responses received after a search for records was complete.
The requester is also interested in the statement “ It is the
intention of the council to publish the outcome of this investigation.” as stated in the councils initial response. The requester would also like to have sight of any recorded information for the basis of this statement in the response.
Yours faithfully,
Marcus Combie

Dear Marcus Combie,
Thank you for your request for information relating to correspondence
relating to processing of FOI / 1038892 which we received on 10/09/2024.
This has been logged as a Freedom of Information Request and will be dealt
with under the Freedom of Information Act 2000. The reference number for
your request can be found above.
The Freedom of Information Act 2000 states that we must respond to you
within 20 working days, by 08/10/2024. Please do not hesitate to contact
us at the email address below if you have any queries.
Yours sincerely,
Sheffield City Council

Dear FOI,
This request is long overdue. Next steps by End of Day will be a complaint to ICO, me accepting Cllr Ben Miskells invitation to discuss the council’s general handling of FOIs.
This is more surprising as all the information requested is within the purview of the FOI dept, and you are the sole information holders who have the information to respond to this.
No outreach to other depts asking for information should be needed.
As per your last reply “Our request is due today but is not quite finished”
You’ve had over a month to complete a request that was “not quite finished”.
Please provide a response today.
Yours sincerely,
Marcus Combie

Dear Mr Combie
Thank you for your request of 10 September 2024 regarding the handling of
your request EIR 1038892. Our legal deadline was 8 October 2024. We
sincerely apologise for our breach of Regulation 5(2) to communicate the
information to you ‘as soon as possible, and no later than 20 working days
after the date of receipt of the request.’ The responsibility lay solely
with the FOI team. Our Inbox is very busy, but we are acutely aware of our
legal obligations and are striving to improve our compliance rate.
There were two elements to your request:
Please provide me with copies of all internal correspondence about the
processing of my Freedom of Information request of Freedom of Information
Request” FOI/EIR Request Regarding Claim of Turret Collapse at the Market
Tavern on 10 January” .
Records will in include but not be limited to, those of the FOI team
reaching out to record custodians, record custodians discussing their
statutory response, any advice sought, and the responses received after a
search for records was complete.
Please find attached.
The requester is also interested in the statement “It is the intention of
the council to publish the outcome of this investigation.” as stated in
the council’s initial response. The requester would also like to have
sight of any recorded information for the basis of this statement in the
response.
Our statement was made on 6 March 2024 in response to your initial request
of 7 February 2024. In that response, which we refused on the grounds that
there was a live investigation into the circumstances around the
demolition of the façade of the Market Tavern, we made the statement
above. Please find attached an email from the Director of Human Resources
upon which this statement was based. We know that this email is dated 6
June 2024, i.e., three months after we replied to you. We cannot find any
previous recorded information in our files. However, our statement
reflected the council’s position at the time.
We have withheld personal data in our attachments. Personal data relates
to identifiable staff, by name and job role. Section 40(2) of FOIA
provides that information is exempt from disclosure if it is the personal
data of an individual other than the requester and where one of the
conditions listed in section 40(3A)(a) is satisfied. This applies where
the disclosure of the information to any member of the public would
contravene any of the principles relating to the processing of personal
data (the DP principles), as set out in Article 5 of the UK General Data
Protection Regulation (UKGDPR).
Article 5(1)(a) of the UK GDPR states that: “Personal data shall be
processed lawfully, fairly and in a transparent manner in relation to the
data subject”. In the case of an FOIA request, the personal data is
processed when it is disclosed in response to the request. This means that
the information can only be disclosed if to do so would be lawful, fair
and transparent. In order to be lawful, one of the lawful bases listed in
Article 6(1) of the GDPR must apply to the processing. It must also be
generally lawful.
Article 6(1) of the UK GDPR specifies the requirements for lawful
processing by providing that “processing shall be lawful only if and to
the extent that at least one of the” conditions listed in the Article
applies. One of the conditions in Article 6(1) must therefore be met
before disclosure of the information in response to the request would be
considered lawful.
The Council considers that the lawful basis most applicable is basis
6(1)(f) which states: “processing is necessary for the purposes of the
legitimate interests pursued by the controller or by a third party except
where such interests are overridden by the interests or fundamental rights
and freedoms of the data subject which require protection of personal
data, in particular where the data subject is a child”.
The Council considers that the lawful basis most likely to be relevant in
relation to a request for information under the FOIA is Article 6(1)(f);
legitimate interests. In considering the application of this provision in
the context of a request for information under FOIA it is necessary to
consider the following three-part test:
i. Legitimate interest test: Whether a legitimate interest is being
pursued in the request for information;
In considering any legitimate interests in the disclosure of the requested
information under the FOIA, we recognise that such interests can include
broad general principles of accountability and transparency for their own
sakes as well as case specific interests. Further, a wide range of
interests may be legitimate interests. They can be the requester’s own
interests or the interests of third parties, and commercial interests as
well as wider societal benefits. They may be compelling or trivial, but
trivial interests may be more easily overridden.
A disclosure under FOI is a disclosure to the world.
We do not consider the disclosure of the names of staff are a legitimate
interest. The staff act for Sheffield City Council and are accountable for
their actions as set out under their contract of employment and supporting
HR policies. Matters relating to staff conduct and performance are an
internal matter. Disclosure to the world must avoid unjustified adverse
effects on the employees concerned. These staff have a reasonable
expectation of privacy.
As there is no legitimate interest, we have not gone on to conduct the
Necessity test nor the Balancing test.
If you have any queries about this response, please do not hesitate to
contact us.
The information provided in this response is available for re-use under
the terms of the Open Government Licence v3.0. The terms of the OGL can be

If you are unhappy with the response you have received in relation to your
request, you are entitled to have this reviewed. You can ask for an
internal review by replying to this email. Internal review requests should
be submitted within 40 working days from the date of this response.
If you remain dissatisfied with the outcome of your internal review, you
can contact the Information Commissioner’s Office. Please see
